title: Alcoa, Ball and Unilever pioneer carbon-free aluminum packaging with ELYSIS technology
summary: Alcoa, in partnership with Ball Corporation and Unilever, announced the first commercial use of **ELYSIS carbon-free aluminum smelting technology** in consumer aerosol packaging.[1] The can uses 50% ELYSIS primary aluminum and 50% post‑consumer recycled content, eliminating direct greenhouse gas emissions from smelting and significantly lowering the packaging’s carbon footprint.[1]

title: Hydro joins Alumobility to accelerate aluminium adoption in the automotive industry
summary: Hydro announced it has joined **Alumobility**, a global ecosystem aimed at advancing aluminium use in lighter, more energy‑efficient and circular vehicles.[2] By contributing its low‑carbon production expertise and full value‑chain capabilities, Hydro seeks to drive innovation in lightweight, sustainable aluminium solutions for automakers worldwide.[2]

title: Aluminum Raw Material Price Trends in January 2026
summary: JASTOO reports that aluminum raw material prices are rising steadily in early 2026, supported by strong global demand and **advancements in sustainable production technologies**.[4] The trend is encouraging investment in R&D for lighter, more energy‑efficient wheel components, aligning with broader automotive sustainability goals.[4]

title: [CES Innovation Awards® 2026 Honoree] Portable SSD T7 Resurrected
summary: Samsung’s Portable SSD **T7 Resurrected** received a CES 2026 Innovation Award for its enclosure made from **100% recycled aluminum** and packaging using recycled paper.[5] The design reuses aluminum scrap from smartphone production and serves as a flagship example of Samsung’s circular‑design strategy to reduce environmental impact across product lines.[5]

title: Aluminum Silos Market Booms: Food Safety, Sustainability Drive Demand and Innovation in Storage Solutions
summary: A new market outlook highlights rapid growth in the **aluminum silos** sector, driven by the need for hygienic food storage, sustainability requirements, and design innovation.[9] The report notes that aluminum’s corrosion resistance, recyclability, and lightweight properties are key factors behind its expanding role in modern, efficient storage infrastructure.[9]

title: Steel – Price, Chart, Historical Data and Market News
summary: Steel rebar futures are trading above 3,120 CNY/ton and near multi‑month highs, supported by expectations that China will roll out new policy measures to bolster economic growth and steel demand.[1] The People’s Bank of China plans to lower the reserve requirement ratio and cut key policy rates in 2026, while current data show steel at 3,128 CNY/ton on January 9, up 0.55% on the day and 1.66% over the past month, though still slightly below year‑ago levels.[1]

title: Steel Prices in the Second Week of January 2026
summary: Global iron and steel markets are experiencing relative price stability in the second week of January 2026, with only limited price movements reported across major regions.[6] The article notes that benchmark prices in key markets have largely plateaued after previous increases, indicating a short‑term consolidation phase in steel pricing trends.[6]

title: CISA mills' daily crude steel output down 11% in late Dec, stocks also down
summary: The China Iron and Steel Association (CISA) reported that in late December 2025 (Dec 21–31), average daily crude steel output at large and medium-sized Chinese mills fell to 1.643 million mt, an 11% decline from mid-December levels.[1] Finished steel inventories at these enterprises also decreased sharply, dropping 11.7% between December 20 and December 31, indicating both reduced production and destocking.[1]

title: Lloyds Engineering Works Signs Technology Licensing Agreement with US-Based The Material Works
summary: Lloyds Engineering Works has entered a strategic technology licensing partnership with U.S.-based The Material Works to deploy **EPS Generation 4** steel surface-cleaning technology.[4] The process replaces traditional acid-based pickling with an eco‑friendly system that uses recyclable materials, achieves zero effluent discharge, and eliminates hazardous acid chemicals, improving both sustainability and production efficiency in steel processing.[4]

title: Copper Pushes Higher With Metals Set for Fourth Weekly Advance
summary: Copper, aluminum and other industrial metals climbed again, extending a strong multi-week rally driven by tightening supplies, increased shipments to the US, and rising investor enthusiasm for commodities.[5] Nickel, tin and copper each gained more than 2% in London, with copper moving back toward its record above $13,300 a tonne set earlier in the week, as the LMEX base metals index headed for a fourth straight weekly advance.[5]

title: Goldman Sachs raises first-half copper price forecast
summary: Goldman Sachs increased its copper price forecast for the first half of 2026 to $12,750 per metric ton from a previous estimate of $11,525, reflecting expectations of continued market tightness.[6] The bank expects robust demand and constrained supply to keep prices elevated, although it also notes that very high levels above recent records may not be sustainable over a longer period.[6]

title: Copper rises with bets on future demand growth
summary: Copper prices advanced on Friday and were set for a fourth consecutive week of gains, supported by renewed bets on future demand growth.[7] The move higher came alongside strength in aluminium and other base metals, as investors positioned for stronger medium-term consumption linked to industrial and energy-transition demand.[7]

title: Copper hits new record of US$13,000/t in London as supply shocks...
summary: Copper reached a record US$13,000 per tonne on the LME, driven by supply disruptions at major mines including Grasberg and Kamoa-Kakula, plus a strike at Capstone Copper's Mantoverde mine in Chile. The market is expected to face a global shortage of over 100,000 tonnes in 2026, with analysts projecting a deficit as supply reliability remains uncertain.

title: The Demand Was Undergoing a Shift Between Old and New Growth...
summary: China's refined copper production reached 1.236 million tons in November 2025, with cumulative production up 9.8% year-on-year through November. Supply is expected to remain tight in 2026, with mine resumptions at Grasberg, Kakula, and Batu Hijau contributing 792,000-961,000 tons, while copper concentrate processing fees have dropped to zero.

title: Chinese demand for copper vanishes after prices hit record
summary: Chinese copper demand has significantly declined following the metal's surge to record prices near $13,000/ton. Refined copper stockpiles in Shanghai have doubled to over 180,000 tons, reaching a 10-year high for the season, while Chinese importers resist high premiums offered by suppliers like Codelco.

title: Copper supplies set to peak just as tech needs more
summary: A fresh study warns that copper demand will likely outstrip production within a decade as electrification, electric vehicles, and AI infrastructure drive consumption. Primary supply faces declining ore grades and rising extraction costs, with new mine development averaging 17 years, while China's dominance of 40-50% of global smelting capacity presents geopolitical risks.

title: Rio Tinto may buy Glencore to form mining leader with copper prices near record
summary: Glencore and Rio Tinto announced merger talks on January 9, 2026, which could create the world's biggest mining company amid soaring metal prices. The deal follows Anglo American's acquisition of Teck Resources and comes as analysts view it as a critical moment for industry consolidation.

title: Copper supplies set to peak just as tech needs more
summary: An analysis of a new S&P Global study warns that global copper demand driven by electrification, electric vehicles, and AI infrastructure is likely to outstrip production within a decade, potentially constraining technological progress and grid expansion.[5] The article highlights challenges such as declining ore grades, long mine development timelines, climate-related water stress at mines, and concentrated smelting capacity in China, and argues that streamlined permitting, new technology, and diversified processing are needed to build a more resilient and sustainable copper supply chain.[5]

title: 'Substantial Shortfall' in Copper Supply Widens as the Race for AI and Growing Defense Spending Add to Accelerating Demand, New S&P Global Study Finds
summary: S&P Global’s new study "Copper in the Age of AI: The Challenges of Electrification" finds that accelerating electrification, AI data centers, EVs and defense demand are projected to push copper demand to 42 million metric tons by 2040, about 50% above current levels, creating a systemic risk if supply does not keep pace.[3][4] The report stresses that closing the looming supply gap will require major investment in new mines, expanded recycling, and policy reforms—such as faster permitting and more stable regulatory regimes—to enable sustainable development of copper needed for the energy transition.[3][4]

title: Nickel price extends drop amid lack of detail on Indonesia output cuts
summary: Nickel retreated from a recent 19‑month high after Indonesia failed to provide details on its pledged production cuts, which had previously driven a sharp price rally.[5] Three‑month LME nickel futures fell as much as 5.9%, settling 4.1% lower at about $17,155/ton, with analysts warning that price sustainability depends on meaningful and consistent quota reductions.[5]

title: Nickel prices hit 15-month high on robust sentiment
summary: Nickel prices on major exchanges climbed to a 15‑month high on 6 January, supported by strong investor sentiment linked to macroeconomic developments and possible changes to Indonesia’s mining plans.[4] LME nickel reached about $18,045/ton, up 7% day‑on‑day and roughly 20% above mid‑December levels, with SHFE nickel also hitting its daily limit.[4]

title: Nickel price surge triggers stainless steel hikes
summary: LME nickel futures jumped nearly 9% in a single session, closing around $18,524/ton on 6 January amid heavy speculative buying and supply concerns.[6] The sharp increase in nickel costs has prompted stainless steel producers to raise prices, citing higher raw‑material input expenses.[6]

title: Global nickel market recalibrates after explosive trading week
summary: Following a volatile week marked by a spike above $18,000/ton, three‑month LME nickel hovered near $17,900/ton as the market reassessed the impact of Indonesia’s planned output cuts and recent speculative flows.[7] Traders reported a shift from aggressive buying to more cautious positioning, with attention focused on how firmly Jakarta will enforce reduced nickel mining quotas.[7]

title: Indonesia releases January (Period I) benchmark prices for nickel ore
summary: Indonesia’s nickel miners association set the January Period I benchmark nickel ore reference price at about $14,630/wmt, a 0.21% increase from late‑December levels.[2] FOB prices for higher‑grade ore rose marginally across Ni 1.6–2.0% grades, reflecting firmer demand and the broader upswing in nickel markets.[2]

title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
summary: Nickel prices surged after Indonesia, the world’s largest producer, announced plans to cut output in 2026 to better balance global supply and demand.[3] Spot nickel rose from $15,800 to $16,500/ton and the three‑month LME contract gained 6.4%, as the market anticipated tighter supply and drew parallels with earlier cobalt quota moves in the DRC.[3]

title: Nickel price extends drop amid lack of detail on Indonesia output cuts
summary: Nickel prices fell sharply from a 19‑month high after Indonesia, the world’s largest nickel producer, failed to provide specifics on planned mining quota cuts that had previously driven a strong price rally.[5] The article notes that three‑month LME nickel futures, which had surged to about $18,800/t on expectations of reduced Indonesian supply, pulled back as analysts warned that any impact on global production capacity may be limited unless meaningful quota reductions are implemented and maintained.[5]

title: Pressure for Indonesian quota U-turn is a risk for nickel price rally
summary: Indonesia’s plan to cut nickel mining quotas has pushed prices close to 19‑month highs, but analysts caution that political and industry pressure could prompt a reversal, limiting the duration of the rally.[7] The piece highlights that Indonesia accounts for roughly 70% of global nickel production capacity, and suggests that new projects coming online and the possibility of higher quotas later in the year could quickly expand effective supply despite the current curbs.[7]

title: Nickel prices hit 15-month high on robust sentiment
summary: Nickel prices climbed to a 15‑month high on strong market sentiment, supported by broader gains in base metals and expectations that Indonesian policy changes may tighten ore supply and raise production costs.[6] Market participants report that Indonesia could cut its nickel ore work plan and budget (RKAB) to 250 million tonnes in 2026 from about 379 million tonnes in 2025, even as domestic ore consumption is projected to rise, implying a potential squeeze on available ore for processing capacity.[6]

title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
summary: Indonesia announced plans to cut nickel production in 2026 to better balance global supply and demand, triggering a jump in nickel prices on the London Metal Exchange.[2] The government intends to adjust miners’ production quotas after years of rapidly rising output that lifted Indonesia’s share of global nickel production from about 31.5% in 2020 to over 60% in 2024, aiming to reduce surplus and support prices while addressing environmental concerns.[2]

title: CRITICAL MINERALS CURRENTS (January 10, 2026)
summary: A critical minerals market update notes that nickel prices have recently hit highs near $18,500/t, supported by investor sentiment and emerging supply constraints.[1] The report situates nickel within broader efforts by the United States and its allies to boost domestic production and reduce reliance on China for critical mineral refining and processing capacity.[1]

title: Harvesting the world's greenest nickel
summary: Metalplant is pioneering a carbon-negative nickel farming operation in Albania's Tropoje region that combines phytomining with enhanced weathering technology. The company uses hyperaccumulating plants to extract nickel while magnesium-rich minerals absorb CO2 from the atmosphere, creating products like HyperNickel and NegativeNickel for use in lithium-ion batteries and green steel.

title: Clean energy supply chains of the future need a circular economy
summary: The article discusses how circular economy approaches can strengthen critical mineral supply chains for the clean energy transition following COP30. It highlights that recycled nickel, cobalt, and lithium produce approximately 80% fewer greenhouse gas emissions than primary mining, creating competitive advantages for low-carbon supply chains.

title: Nickel Market Volume Expected at 4.4 Mn Tons by 2031 on Strong Stainless Steel and EV Demand
summary: Market analysis projects nickel demand will reach 4.4 million tons by 2031, driven by stainless steel and electric vehicle battery production. North America is developing domestic nickel supply projects aligned with clean energy and EV manufacturing needs.

title: Greenland grants 30-year permit to EU-backed molybdenum mine
summary: Greenland Resources has received a 30-year exploitation license for its Malmbjerg molybdenum project, a strategic mine backed by the European Union.[9] The company previously signed offtake agreements with Finland’s Outokumpu and Italy’s Cogne Acciai Speciali, positioning the project as an important future supplier of molybdenum to European stainless steel and specialty steel producers.[9]

title: Tenaris reduced pipe sales to 2.95 million tons in January-September
summary: Tenaris sold 2.95 million tons of pipe products in the first nine months of 2025, representing a 2% decrease compared to the same period in the previous year. This reflects market conditions affecting the international pipe company's sales performance.

title: Tenaris S A: Buy-back transactions - Weekly Report (December 29, 2025 - January 2, 2026)
summary: Tenaris repurchased 3,320,025 ordinary shares between December 29, 2025 and January 2, 2026 as part of its second tranche of the $1.2 billion share buyback program. The shares will be cancelled as part of the company's capital management strategy.

title: Tenaris Launches $600M Second Tranche Under $1.2B Buyback
summary: Tenaris announced the second $600 million tranche of its $1.2 billion share buyback program, running from November 3, 2025 to April 30, 2026. The program was authorized by shareholders on May 6, 2025, with purchased shares to be cancelled.

title: BofA Sees Growth Potential for Prysmian from US Tariffs
summary: Bank of America said that newly announced US copper and aluminum tariffs could significantly benefit Prysmian, given that almost all of its copper cable production is now in the US and largely based on locally sourced recycled material.[1] The bank estimates Prysmian could lift copper cable prices by about 10%, potentially adding €500 million to €1 billion to 2026 EBITDA, especially in medium- and low-voltage cable segments now facing average import tariffs of 41%.[1]

title: World’s top cable maker sees US copper tariff as opportunity
summary: Prysmian, the world’s largest copper cable manufacturer, said it views the planned 50% US tariff on copper as an opportunity that will strengthen the American supply chain, with higher costs expected to be passed on to customers.[2] The Italian group, which recently spent over $4 billion to acquire Texas-based Encore Wire, believes it is better positioned than rivals because it sources a large share of its copper domestically and is vertically integrated in its US operations.[2]
